title: Auto-close epics when all children complete
description:
# Overview
Add automatic epic closure to atari. After successfully closing a bead, asynchronously close any parent epics whose children are all complete.

# Implementation Issues
- bd-drain-vnyt: Add EpicClosedEvent and closeEligibleEpics method
- bd-drain-96cq: Integration test for epic auto-closure

# Key Decisions
- Asynchronous fire-and-forget (does not block next bead)
- Log errors, do not propagate (non-fatal)
- New EpicClosedEvent with full context
- One event per epic closed
- 10 second timeout
- Always enabled (no config flag)

# Verification
- `golangci-lint run` passes
- `go test -v ./...` passes

# Success Criteria
All implementation issues closed and tests pass.
close_reason: Completed: All child beads closed. EpicClosedEvent type added, closeEligibleEpics method implemented in controller, integration tests verify epic auto-closure works correctly for multi-child, single-child, and no-eligible-epic scenarios.

title: TUI Integration Tests
description:
# Overview

Add integration tests for the TUI component to catch wiring bugs between TUI and controller, observer, and graph fetcher.

# Scope

This epic covers adding integration tests for the TUI that verify end-to-end flows rather than isolated unit tests. The TUI currently has 10 unit test files but zero integration tests, causing bugs to slip through (e.g., missing WithGraphFetcher bug).

# Implementation Issues

- bd-drain-ca0: Add TUI integration test infrastructure
- bd-drain-smz: Add TUI event flow integration tests
- bd-drain-7hw: Add TUI callback integration tests
- bd-drain-5gr: Add TUI graph pane integration tests
- bd-drain-7sy: Add TUI observer pane integration tests
- bd-drain-bo3: Add teatest smoke test for TUI lifecycle
- bd-drain-4cg: Run full test suite (final verification)

# Verification Commands

- Lint: mise run lint
- Tests: mise run test

# Key Trade-offs

1. Tests placed in internal/tui/ package (not internal/integration/) to access unexported types like model and newModel. Trade-off: tighter coupling to implementation, but necessary for thorough testing.

2. teatest used only for one lifecycle smoke test, not all tests. Trade-off: less coverage of bubbletea runtime behavior, but avoids timing flakiness.

3. Config wiring tests deferred to separate issue. Trade-off: some CLI flag propagation bugs may slip through until that issue is completed.

# Success Criteria

All implementation issues closed and final verification passes with no test failures.
close_reason: All TUI integration test issues complete: (1) bd-drain-ca0: test infrastructure, (2) bd-drain-smz: event flow tests, (3) bd-drain-7hw: callback tests, (4) bd-drain-5gr: graph pane tests, (5) bd-drain-7sy: observer pane tests, (6) bd-drain-bo3: teatest lifecycle smoke test, (7) bd-drain-4cg: final verification. All tests pass, no regressions.

title: Implement Unix socket server with JSON-RPC protocol
description:
# Description

Implement the Unix socket server and JSON-RPC protocol for daemon communication. This enables CLI commands to control the running daemon.

# Relevant Files

- internal/daemon/server.go (new file)
- internal/daemon/protocol.go (new file)
- internal/daemon/handlers.go (new file)
- docs/components/daemon.md:157-273 (server specification)

# Implementation

1. Create internal/daemon/protocol.go:
   - Request struct with Method and ID fields
   - Response struct with Result, Error, and ID fields
   - StatusResponse struct with Status, CurrentBead, Uptime, StartTime, Stats
   - StatusStats struct matching workqueue.QueueStats

2. Create internal/daemon/server.go:
   - serve(ctx) - accept loop with graceful shutdown
   - handleConnection(ctx, conn) - read request, dispatch, write response
   - Use json.Decoder/Encoder with io.LimitedReader (1MB max)
   - Set 30s read deadline per connection
   - Set socket permissions to 0600

3. Create internal/daemon/handlers.go:
   - handleRequest(ctx, req) - dispatch to method handlers
   - handleStatus() - return StatusResponse from controller
   - handlePause() - call controller.Pause()
   - handleResume() - call controller.Resume()
   - handleStop(force bool) - call controller.Stop(), schedule daemon shutdown

4. Add Start(ctx) and Stop() methods to Daemon struct

# Acceptance Criteria

- Socket accepts connections and handles JSON-RPC requests
- All four methods work: status, pause, resume, stop
- Stop with force param triggers immediate shutdown
- Connection timeout prevents hung clients
- Message size limit prevents DoS
- Socket permissions are 0600

# Verification

- [ ] `mise run lint` passes
- [ ] `mise run test` passes
- [ ] Manual test: start daemon, send status request via nc or socat
close_reason: Implemented Unix socket server with JSON-RPC protocol: protocol.go with Request/Response/StatusResponse types, server.go with Start/Stop and accept loop, handlers.go with status/pause/resume/stop handlers. Added security measures: 1MB message limit, 30s timeout, 0600 socket permissions. Tests include shortSocketPath helper for macOS socket path limits. Verified with mise run lint (0 issues) and mise run test (all pass).

title: Graceful pause with context preservation
description:
# Epic: Graceful Pause with Context Preservation

Wire up existing GracefulPause() functionality and add session resume capability to preserve context across pause/resume cycles.

## Goal
Enable atari to pause at turn boundaries (instead of waiting for full bead completion) and resume with full context preserved via Claude Code's --resume flag.

## Key Features
1. Graceful pause stops at turn boundary
2. Wrap-up prompt gives Claude chance to save notes
3. Session ID captured and stored
4. Resume uses --resume to restore context

## Key Decisions (from user interview)
- Default pause behavior: graceful (turn boundary)
- TUI and CLI behave the same
- Wrap-up asks for notes only (not commit)
- 60s wrap-up timeout
- Session ID stored in state file and bead notes
- Stale session IDs fall back to fresh session

title: Fix cost tracking double-count bug
description:
# Description
Fix the cost/turns double-counting issue in StateSink and ensure cost data flows correctly from parser to TUI.

## Problem
1. StateSink adds cost for BOTH SessionEndEvent AND IterationEndEvent (double-count)
2. Controller.runSession() returns empty SessionResult{} - cost is always zero in IterationEndEvent
3. TUI shows $0.00 because it reads from IterationEndEvent

## Solution

### Part 1: Parser captures session result
- Add `result atomic.Value` field to Parser struct
- In handleResultEvent(), store event in atomic.Value before emitting
- Add Result() method that returns captured *SessionEndEvent
- Use atomic.Value for thread-safe access (parser runs in goroutine)

### Part 2: Controller retrieves result
- After parser.Parse() completes, call parser.Result()
- Populate SessionResult with NumTurns, TotalCostUSD from parser result
- Handle nil result gracefully (log warning, return zero values)

### Part 3: Fix double-count in StateSink
- Add `countedSessions map[string]bool` to StateSink
- In SessionEndEvent handler: only add cost if session not already counted
- In IterationEndEvent handler: mark session as counted after adding cost
- IterationEndEvent is authoritative source for totals

## Files to modify
- internal/session/parser.go - Add result capture and Result() method
- internal/controller/controller.go - Retrieve parser result in runSession()
- internal/events/statesink.go - Add session deduplication

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] TUI displays actual cost from Claude session (not $0.00)
- [ ] State file totals match TUI display
- [ ] No double-counting when both events fire
- [ ] Tests verify cost flow end-to-end

## Verification
- [ ] `mise run lint` passes
- [ ] `mise run test` passes
- [ ] Manual: Run atari, process a bead, verify cost > $0 in TUI
close_reason: Fixed cost tracking double-count bug. Parser now captures SessionEndEvent via Result() method for controller retrieval. StateSink uses countedSessions map to prevent double-counting when both events fire. Tests verify cost flow end-to-end. Lint and tests pass.

title: Add header-only monitoring view when all panels closed
description:
# Description

When all TUI panels (events, observer, graph) are closed, the TUI should display a header-only monitoring view instead of falling through to an events view with missing keybinds.

Currently:
- Closing the last panel leaves focusedPane stale
- View() falls through to renderEventsOnlyView() even when eventsOpen is false
- renderFooter() returns empty string because no switch cases match

Users want to close all panels to monitor only status and cost. This should be a supported workflow.

# Implementation

1. Add allPanesClosed() helper to check if events, observer, and graph are all closed

2. Update View() to detect all-panels-closed state and render header-only view

3. Create renderHeaderOnlyView():
   - Show header (status, cost, bead info, stats) - full screen, maybe enlarged
   - Show keybinds footer so users can reopen panels
   - Optionally show some centered information or recent events summary

4. Update toggle functions:
   - Remove guard in toggleEvents that prevents closing when its the only panel
   - Fix focus handling when closing last panel (set to a neutral state)

5. Update footer logic to handle all-panels-closed state with appropriate keybinds (e/o/b to open panels, q to quit, etc.)

# Relevant Files

- internal/tui/model.go:164-222 - toggleEvents, toggleObserver, toggleGraph functions
- internal/tui/view.go:17-47 - View() main dispatch logic
- internal/tui/view.go:726-742 - renderFooter() with switch cases
- internal/tui/model.go:421-424 - anyPaneOpen() helper
close_reason: Implemented header-only monitoring view when all TUI panels closed. Added allPanesClosed() helper, renderHeaderOnlyView() with centered message and hints, renderHeaderOnlyFooter() with keybinds, updated View() dispatch logic, removed toggleEvents guard. Tests added and passing. Verified with lint and tests.

title: Add filtered read methods to JSONL reader
description:
# Description

Add status-filtered read methods to the JSONL reader to support Active, Backlog, and Closed views.

# Context

The BeadFetcher interface requires FetchActive, FetchBacklog, and FetchClosed methods. The JSONL reader needs corresponding filtered methods that reuse the existing filtering logic.

# Implementation

Add to `internal/tui/jsonl_reader.go`:

1. **ReadActive() method**:
   - Call ReadAll()
   - Apply filterByStatus(beads, "open", "in_progress", "blocked")
   - Apply filterOutAgentBeads(beads)
   - Return filtered beads

2. **ReadBacklog() method**:
   - Call ReadAll()
   - Apply filterByStatus(beads, "deferred")
   - Apply filterOutAgentBeads(beads)
   - Return filtered beads

3. **ReadClosed(days int) method**:
   - Call ReadAll()
   - Apply filterByStatus(beads, "closed")
   - Apply filterClosedWithinDays(beads, days)
   - Apply filterOutAgentBeads(beads)
   - Return filtered beads

4. **Update parseTimestamp**:
   - Add time.RFC3339Nano to format list (first position)
   - Ensures fractional-second timestamps from JSONL parse correctly

# Relevant Files

- `internal/tui/jsonl_reader.go` - add new methods
- `internal/tui/fetcher.go` - existing filter functions to reuse, parseTimestamp to update

# Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] ReadActive returns only open/in_progress/blocked beads
- [ ] ReadBacklog returns only deferred beads
- [ ] ReadClosed returns beads closed within N days
- [ ] Agent beads filtered from all views
- [ ] RFC3339Nano timestamps parse correctly

## Verification
- [ ] `mise run lint` passes
- [ ] `mise run test` passes

title: Add TUI graph pane integration tests
description:
# Description

Test that the graph pane correctly fetches bead data via BDFetcher and renders the dependency graph.

# Context

GraphPane calls BDFetcher.FetchActive/FetchBacklog which executes bd list --json. The response is parsed and rendered as a graph. Discovery identified a staleness race condition where out-of-order responses could cause stuck loading states.

# Implementation

Create tests in internal/tui/graph_integration_test.go covering:

1. Initial fetch loads beads from MockRunner bd list response
2. Refresh key R triggers re-fetch with new request ID
3. View toggle a switches between Active and Backlog views
4. Fetch error displays error message in pane
5. Navigation with j/k/h/l updates selected node
6. Enter key emits GraphOpenModalMsg with correct node ID
7. Staleness test: out-of-order responses with different requestIDs
8. Only newer requestID result is accepted

Use MockRunner with SetResponse for bd list JSON responses. Use graph_fixtures.go for test data.

# Relevant files

- internal/tui/graph_pane.go - GraphPane implementation
- internal/tui/fetcher.go - BDFetcher implementation
- internal/testutil/graph_fixtures.go - test JSON data

# Acceptance criteria

- [ ] At least 6 test cases passing
- [ ] Staleness race condition test passes
- [ ] MockRunner responses correctly parsed
- [ ] Navigation updates selectedID

- [ ] mise run test passes

title: Reimplement activity stream as JSONL file watcher
description:
# Description
Replace the bd activity --follow streaming with a file watcher on .beads/issues.jsonl. beads_rust auto-flushes after mutations, so the JSONL file stays current.

# Current Implementation
- internal/bdactivity/watcher.go spawns `bd activity --follow --json`
- internal/bdactivity/parser.go parses typed events (create, status, update, comment)
- Emits BeadCreatedEvent, BeadStatusEvent, BeadUpdatedEvent, BeadCommentEvent, BeadClosedEvent

# New Implementation
- Use fsnotify to watch .beads/issues.jsonl for changes
- Track file position, tail new lines on change
- Emit simplified BeadChangedEvent{BeadID, OldState, NewState} 
- Handle file truncation (br sync rewrites): detect and re-read from start

# Files to Modify

title: Add parallel bead enrichment to fetcher
description:
# Description

Add `enrichBeadsWithDetails()` helper to fetcher.go that enriches basic beads from `bd list` with full dependency data from `bd show`.

# Background

`bd list --json` returns beads with null/empty dependencies arrays. The graph needs dependency data to build parent-child hierarchy for epic collapsing. `bd show <id> --json` returns full dependency data.

# Technical Approach

1. Add private helper `enrichBeadsWithDetails(ctx, beads []GraphBead) ([]GraphBead, error)`:
   - For each bead, call `bd show <id> --json` in parallel
   - Use semaphore to limit concurrency (max 5 concurrent)
   - On individual failure, retain basic data from bd list
   - Return slice of enriched beads

2. Use `golang.org/x/sync/semaphore` for rate limiting

3. Error handling:
   - Context timeout propagates to all goroutines
   - Individual bd show failures logged, bead keeps basic data
   - Return partial results on partial failure

# Relevant Files

- internal/tui/fetcher.go - Add enrichBeadsWithDetails helper
- internal/tui/fetcher_test.go - Add parallel fetch tests

# Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] enrichBeadsWithDetails fetches full bead data for all beads
- [ ] Parallel fetching limited to 5 concurrent calls
- [ ] Individual failures don't block other fetches
- [ ] Context cancellation stops all in-flight fetches

# Verification

- [ ] `golangci-lint run` passes
- [ ] `go test -v ./internal/tui/...` passes

If implementation reveals new issues, create separate bd issues for investigation.
close_reason: Added enrichBeadsWithDetails helper to fetcher.go that enriches beads with full dependency data from bd show in parallel. Uses semaphore for max 5 concurrent fetches. Individual failures retain basic data. Tests cover enrichment, partial failure, context cancellation, and concurrency limits. All tests and lint pass.

title: Add integration test for epic auto-closure
description:
# Description
Add integration test verifying epics are automatically closed when all children complete.

# Technical Approach

1. Create test in `internal/integration/` or extend existing integration tests
2. Test scenario:
   - Create an epic with 2-3 child beads
   - Configure atari to process the beads
   - Verify each bead gets closed
   - Verify epic is auto-closed after last child completes
   - Verify EpicClosedEvent is emitted

# Test Setup
- Use real bd commands against test fixture
- Create temporary .beads directory for isolation
- Clean up after test

# Key Assertions
- Epic starts with status "open"
- After all children closed, epic status is "closed"
- EpicClosedEvent emitted with correct fields:
  - EpicID matches created epic
  - TriggeringBeadID is the last closed child
  - TotalChildren matches actual count

# Edge Cases to Test
- Single child epic
- Multiple children completing in sequence

title: Implement events package router
description:
# Description

Create the channel-based pub/sub event router that allows components to emit events and sinks to subscribe to them.

## Scope

Create `internal/events/router.go` with:

1. **Router struct**:
   ```go
   type Router struct {
       subscribers []subscriberEntry
       bufferSize  int
       mu          sync.RWMutex
       closed      bool
   }
   
   type subscriberEntry struct {
       ch       chan Event
       blocking bool
   }
   ```

2. **Core methods**:
   - `NewRouter(bufferSize int) *Router` - Constructor with default buffer size
   - `Emit(event Event)` - Publish event to all subscribers
   - `Subscribe() <-chan Event` - Get buffered event channel
   - `SubscribeBuffered(size int) <-chan Event` - Custom buffer size
   - `Unsubscribe(ch <-chan Event)` - Remove subscription
   - `Close()` - Close all subscriber channels

3. **Emit behavior**:
   - Non-blocking send to buffered subscribers (drop on full)
   - Log warning when events are dropped (use slog)

4. **Thread safety**:
   - RWMutex protects subscriber list
   - Emit uses read lock, Subscribe/Unsubscribe use write lock

## Design Decisions

- Default buffer size: 100 events
- Drop policy: non-blocking send, log warning on drop
- State sink should use SubscribeBuffered(1000) to reduce drops
- Close() closes all channels, subsequent Emit() is no-op

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Single subscriber receives all emitted events
- [ ] Multiple subscribers each receive all events
- [ ] Unsubscribe removes subscriber correctly
- [ ] Close() closes all channels
- [ ] Full buffer results in drop + warning log
- [ ] Thread-safe under concurrent access

## Relevant Files

- `internal/events/router.go` (create)
- `internal/events/router_test.go` (create)
- `docs/components/events.md` (reference)

## Verification

- [ ] `mise run fmt` passes
- [ ] `mise run lint` passes
- [ ] `mise run test` passes
- [ ] `mise run build` passes

If implementation reveals new issues, create separate bd issues for investigation.

Implemented events package router with:
- Router struct with channel-based pub/sub
- NewRouter(bufferSize) constructor with default of 100
- Emit() with non-blocking send and slog warning on drop
- Subscribe() and SubscribeBuffered() for custom buffer sizes
- Unsubscribe() and Close() for cleanup
- Comprehensive tests covering single/multiple subscribers, unsubscribe, close, full buffer drops, and concurrent access

title: Fix observer blocked when drain session is active
description:
# Description

The observer times out with 'failed to acquire session: session broker: acquisition timeout' when asking questions while atari is actively draining a bead. This contradicts the documented purpose of observer mode.

Documentation states (docs/components/observer.md line 9): 'Ask questions about what Claude is doing without pausing the drain'

But the SessionBroker enforces mutual exclusion, making observer unusable during drain.

# Root Cause

- Controller acquires broker with 'drain' holder at internal/controller/controller.go:415
- Broker is held for entire duration of session processing (many minutes)
- Observer has only 5-second timeout (defaultAcquireTimeout in internal/observer/observer.go:21)
- When observer calls broker.Acquire() at observer.go:85, it times out immediately

# Relevant Files

- internal/observer/broker.go - SessionBroker implementation
- internal/observer/observer.go:21 - defaultAcquireTimeout = 5 * time.Second
- internal/observer/observer.go:82-88 - Ask() acquires broker
- internal/controller/controller.go:413-418 - drain acquires broker for entire session
- docs/components/observer.md - documents intended concurrent behavior

# Options to Consider

1. Remove mutual exclusion: Allow observer to run separate Claude (haiku) session while drain runs. May be fine since they are separate processes using different models.

2. Better error messaging: Show 'Drain session is active - wait for current bead to complete' with holder info instead of generic timeout.

3. Preemption: Let observer temporarily pause drain session (complex, may cause issues).

4. Queue with notification: Queue question until drain releases broker, notify user of wait.

Option 1 seems most aligned with documented intent. The broker may have been overly conservative.

# Acceptance Criteria

- Observer can ask questions while drain session is active
- OR clear UX indicating why query cannot be executed and when it can
- Documentation matches implementation behavior
close_reason: Fixed by removing broker.Acquire/Release from observer.Ask() - observer now runs independently while drain is active. Observer and drain use different models and processes, so there is no need for mutual exclusion. Updated tests to verify concurrent operation and documentation to reflect the change. Lint and tests pass.

title: Block panel toggle keys in INSERT mode
description:
Panel toggle keys (e, o, b, E, B, O) are not blocked when observer is in INSERT mode. When typing in the observer textarea, these letters trigger panel toggles instead of being typed.

Root cause: update.go handleKey() processes panel toggles at lines 198-248 BEFORE checking observer focus at line 251.

Fix: Add early guard clause after modal check but before panel toggles:

if m.observerOpen and m.isObserverFocused() and m.observerPane.IsInsertMode() then forward key to observer pane instead of processing as global command. Exception: ctrl+c, esc, tab still pass through.

Files:
- internal/tui/update.go - Add guard clause after line 141
- internal/tui/update_test.go - Add tests for insert mode key blocking

Acceptance Criteria:
- In INSERT mode, typing e/o/b types those letters (not toggle panels)
- Esc still exits insert mode
- Tab still cycles focus
- ctrl+c still works for cancel/quit

Verification:
- golangci-lint run passes
- go test -v ./internal/tui/... passes
close_reason: Panel toggle keys (e, o, b, etc.) are now blocked in INSERT mode. Keys forwarded to observer textarea instead of triggering global commands. Ctrl+c, esc, tab still pass through. Verified: lint passes, TUI tests pass.

title: Phase 7: Bead Visualization
description:
# Overview

Interactive TUI pane for visualizing bead relationships, status, and hierarchy. This is Phase 7 of the Atari implementation plan.

# Scope

- Graph pane showing epic/task hierarchy and blocking dependencies
- Three toggleable panels (events/observer/graph) with focus mode
- Node density levels (compact/standard/detailed)
- Detail modal showing full bead information
- Active/Backlog view toggle
- Collapsible epics
- Current bead highlighting during drain
- Viewport scrolling for large graphs

# Implementation Issues

- bd-drain-ejp: Add GraphConfig to configuration system
- bd-drain-7p4: Add graph data types and BeadFetcher
- bd-drain-i2a: Implement Graph data structure and layout algorithm
- bd-drain-1lp: Implement Graph rendering with density levels
- bd-drain-fbx: Implement GraphPane TUI component
- bd-drain-s68: Extend TUI panel system for 3-pane layouts
- bd-drain-shc: Implement detail modal and controller integration
- bd-drain-cnr: Run full test suite (final verification)

# Verification Commands

- Lint: `mise run lint`
- Tests: `mise run test`
- Integration: `go test -v ./internal/integration/...`
- Build: `mise run build`

# Key Design Decisions

- Data source: `bd list --json --status ...` with embedded dependencies
- Panel ordering: Fixed (events | observer | graph)
- Layout direction: Top-down for horizontal splits, left-right for vertical
- Priority-based pane hiding when terminal too small
- Leading-edge debounce for refresh with trailing update
- Lazy `bd show` fetch for modal details
- "N deps hidden" pseudo-node for missing dependencies

# Key Trade-offs

1. **Fixed panel order** vs enable-order: Simpler, predictable layout
2. **Manual refresh** vs auto-refresh: User control, no performance concerns
3. **Pseudo-node for missing deps** vs individual placeholders: Cleaner graphs
4. **BFS layer layout** vs force-directed: Simpler, deterministic, good for trees

# Success Criteria

All implementation issues closed and final verification passes.

# Documentation

- Component spec: docs/components/graph.md
- Implementation plan: docs/IMPLEMENTATION.md (Phase 7 section)

title: JSONL-based bead hierarchy visualization
description:
# Overview

Enable TUI bead visualization to show epic/task parent-child relationships by reading dependencies directly from `.beads/issues.jsonl` instead of relying on `bd list --json` which doesn't include dependency data.

# Scope

This epic covers:
- Creating a JSONL reader that parses issues.jsonl with full dependency information
- Implementing BeadFetcher interface using JSONL data
- Wiring auto-detection into CLI to use JSONL when available
- Comprehensive testing of the new functionality

# Implementation Issues

- bd-drain-d7a: Add JSONL reader for bead dependencies
- bd-drain-f09: Add JSONL reader unit tests
- bd-drain-2wn: Add filtered read methods to JSONL reader
- bd-drain-0r3: Implement JSONLFetcher with BeadFetcher interface
- bd-drain-m0d: Wire JSONL fetcher into TUI with auto-detection
- bd-drain-d9k: Run full test suite for JSONL hierarchy (final verification)

# Verification Commands

- Lint: `mise run lint`
- Tests: `mise run test`
- Integration: `go test ./internal/integration/...`
- Full E2E: `mise run bake`

# Key Trade-offs

1. **Auto-detect vs config flag**: Chose auto-detection based on file existence for simplicity. No config changes needed.

2. **Dependents computation**: JSONL doesn't store dependents, so we compute them from reverse index. Slightly more processing but maintains feature parity with bd show.

3. **Defer caching**: Initial implementation reads file fresh each time. File is small enough (~50KB) that performance target is met without caching.

4. **Single-read snapshot**: Use os.ReadFile for consistency vs streaming. Simpler and handles partial writes gracefully.

# Success Criteria

All implementation issues closed and final verification passes with:
- Hierarchy visualization working in all views
- Tree glyphs rendering correctly
- Collapse/expand functional
- Performance under 100ms

All tests pass, Docker builds successfully.

title: Fix TUI epic collapse in active view
description:
# Overview
Fix epic collapse functionality in the TUI graph active view by enriching beads with full dependency data from bd show.

# Problem
bd list --json returns beads with null/empty dependencies, but ExtractEdges() needs dependency data to build parent-child hierarchy edges. Without edges, collapse has nothing to collapse.

# Solution
Enrich all beads with bd show after bd list, using parallel fetching with semaphore rate limiting.

# Implementation Issues
- bd-drain-673g: Add parallel bead enrichment to fetcher
- bd-drain-h5l6: Integrate bead enrichment into FetchActive/Backlog/Closed
- bd-drain-9if8: Remove fetchMissingDeps from graph.go
- bd-drain-x9lj: Add tests for epic collapse with enriched data
- bd-drain-kwbk: Run full test suite (final verification)

# Verification Commands
- Lint: golangci-lint run
- Tests: go test -v ./...

# Key Trade-offs
- Parallel fetch with semaphore (5 concurrent) vs sequential: Chose parallel for better UX on large bead sets
- Fresh fetch vs caching: Chose always-fresh to avoid cache invalidation complexity
- Enrich all beads vs only epics: Chose all beads since we need dependency data on children too

# Success Criteria
All implementation issues closed and tests pass. Epic collapse works in active/backlog/closed views.

title: Implement turn-boundary graceful pause
description:
[3m[32m# Description[0m
Implement graceful pause that interrupts Claude sessions at turn boundaries rather than waiting [1m[1m[35mfor[0m full iteration completion[1m[30m.[0m This allows users to pause quickly [1m[1m[35mwhile[0m still getting a proper checkpoint[1m[30m.[0m

[3m[32m# Problem[0m
Current pause behavior waits [1m[1m[35mfor[0m the entire bead iteration to complete, which can take many minutes[1m[30m.[0m Users expect pause to be responsive[1m[30m.[0m

[3m[32m# Solution: Turn-Boundary Interruption[0m

Based on Claude Code architecture investigation:
[1m[30m-[0m `[1m[30m--[0mresume` is [1m[1m[35mfor[0m continuing conversations, NOT crash recovery
[1m[30m-[0m Killing mid[1m[30m-[0mexecution leaves partial state that [1m[30m--[0mresume cannot recover
[1m[30m-[0m Turn boundaries (between [1m[1m[35mtool[0m calls) are clean pause points

[3m[32m## Implementation[0m

[3m[32m### 1. Use --max-turns for frequent pause points[0m
Update session spawning to use smaller [1m[35mmax[0m[1m[30m-[0mturns values:
```go
[1m[30m//[0m Instead of [1m[30m--[0m[1m[35mmax[0m[1m[30m-[0mturns [1m[30m50[0m, use smaller batches
args [1m[30m=[0m append(args, [1m[30m"--max-turns"[0m, [1m[30m"10"[0m)
```

[3m[32m### 2. Detect turn boundaries in stream-json[0m
Parse stream[1m[30m-[0mjson output to detect when turns complete:
[1m[30m-[0m Look [1m[1m[35mfor[0m turn completion markers [1m[1m[35min[0m the stream
[1m[30m-[0m Track when [1m[1m[35mtool[0m call batches finish
[1m[30m-[0m These are safe points to interrupt

[3m[32m### 3. Pause flow[0m
When pause requested:
[1m[30m1.[0m Set pauseRequested flag
[1m[30m2.[0m Wait [1m[1m[35mfor[0m current turn to complete (detected via stream[1m[30m-[0mjson parsing)
[1m[30m3.[0m Kill process at turn boundary (state is clean)
[1m[30m4.[0m Spawn checkpoint session:
   ```bash
   claude [1m[30m--[0mresume [1m[30m<[0msession_id[1m[30m>[0m [1m[30m-[0mp [1m[30m"Session paused by user. Write a detailed checkpoint comment on bead <bead_id> using 'bd comment <bead_id> <message>'. Include: COMPLETED (what is done), IN PROGRESS (current state), NEXT (exact next step for resumption)."[0m
   ```
[1m[30m5.[0m Wait [1m[1m[35mfor[0m checkpoint session to complete
[1m[30m6.[0m Atari is now paused with checkpoint written

[3m[32m### 4. Resume flow[0m
When resume requested:
[1m[30m-[0m Start fresh session on the paused bead
[1m[30m-[0m Bead already has checkpoint comment with full context
[1m[30m-[0m New session reads bead [1m[1m[35mand[0m continues from checkpoint

[3m[32m# Relevant Files[0m
[1m[30m-[0m internal[1m[30m/[0mcontroller[1m[30m/[0mcontroller[1m[30m.[0mgo [1m[30m-[0m Pause[1m[30m/[0mresume logic
[1m[30m-[0m internal[1m[30m/[0msession[1m[30m/[0mmanager[1m[30m.[0mgo [1m[30m-[0m Session spawning with [1m[30m--[0m[1m[35mmax[0m[1m[30m-[0mturns
[1m[30m-[0m internal[1m[30m/[0msession[1m[30m/[0mparser[1m[30m.[0mgo [1m[30m-[0m Stream[1m[30m-[0mjson parsing [1m[1m[35mfor[0m turn detection
[1m[30m-[0m internal[1m[30m/[0mconfig[1m[30m/[0mconfig[1m[30m.[0mgo [1m[30m-[0m Add TurnsPerBatch config option

[3m[32m# Design Decisions[0m
[1m[30m-[0m Smaller [1m[30m--[0m[1m[35mmax[0m[1m[30m-[0mturns ([1m[30m10[0m) creates more pause opportunities but slightly more overhead
[1m[30m-[0m Turn boundary detection is safer than arbitrary interruption
[1m[30m-[0m Checkpoint is a bd comment (visible [1m[1m[35min[0m bead history) [1m[1m[35mnot[0m just notes
[1m[30m-[0m Fresh session on resume (bead has all context needed)

[1m[30m-[0m [ ] Resume starts fresh session that can read checkpoint

# Description

If implementation reveals new issues, create separate bd issues for investigation.

title: Clear observer history on pane close
description:
# Description

When the observer pane is closed and reopened, the chat history persists instead of being cleared. Users expect a fresh context when reopening the observer.

# Root Cause

The toggleObserver() function in internal/tui/model.go only toggles the observerOpen boolean - it never calls ClearResponse() to clear the history.

# Relevant Files

- internal/tui/model.go:181-199 - toggleObserver() needs to call ClearResponse() when closing
- internal/tui/observer_pane.go:498-503 - ClearResponse() method already exists and works

# Fix

In toggleObserver(), when m.observerOpen transitions from true to false, call m.observerPane.ClearResponse().
close_reason: Added ClearResponse() call in toggleObserver() when closing the observer pane. Now when the pane is closed and reopened, the chat history is cleared as expected. Verified with tests and lint.

title: Implement TUI graceful degradation
description:
# Description
Create fallback mode for environments without TTY support. The TUI should detect non-interactive terminals and fall back to simple line-by-line output.

# Relevant Files
- internal/tui/fallback.go: TTY detection and simple output mode
- internal/tui/tui.go: Integration with Run() method
- golang.org/x/term: TTY detection dependency

# Implementation
1. Create fallback.go with detection functions:
   - isTerminal(): Check both stdout AND stdin are TTY
   - terminalSize(): Get current terminal dimensions
   - terminalTooSmall(): Check if below 60x15 minimum
2. Implement runSimple() method:
   - Read events from channel in loop
   - Format each event using Format() function
   - Print to stdout with timestamp prefix
   - Exit when channel closes
   - Handle ctrl+c for early exit
3. Update tui.go Run() method:
   - Check isTerminal() at startup
   - If not terminal: call runSimple() directly
   - If terminal too small: call runSimple() directly
   - Otherwise: run full bubbletea TUI
4. Note: Dynamic switching between full/minimal modes happens within Tea (not runSimple)
   - runSimple is startup-only fallback
   - Within Tea, resize below minimum shows tooSmall message

# Acceptance Criteria
- Non-TTY environments get line output
- Small terminals get line output at startup
- Format() is reused for consistency
- Ctrl+c exits cleanly in simple mode
- Channel closure exits cleanly

## Verification
- [ ] mise run lint passes
- [ ] mise run test passes
- [ ] Manual test: pipe output to file, verify line format

If implementation reveals new issues, create separate bd issues for investigation.
close_reason: TUI graceful degradation implemented in internal/tui/fallback.go with isTerminal(), terminalSize(), terminalTooSmall() detection and runSimple() fallback for non-TTY environments. Tests in fallback_test.go. Verified with mise run lint and mise run test.

title: Fix graph node rendering corruption
description:
# Description
Graph nodes render on top of each other because ANSI escape codes from lipgloss styling corrupt character positions.

# Root cause
1. formatNode() calls style.Render(text) adding ANSI codes
2. writeString() uses byte offset (i in range) as character position
3. charGrid.styles field exists but is unused

# Relevant files
- internal/tui/graph.go:788-812 - formatNode applies styles too early
- internal/tui/graph.go:955-960 - writeString uses byte offset
- internal/tui/graph.go:921-969 - charGrid has unused styles field

# Fix approach
Option A: Remove styling from formatNode, apply at final render
Option B: Complete the styles field implementation - store plain text + style, apply in String()
close_reason: Added regression tests for graph node rendering corruption fix. Tests verify: (1) writeStyledString places characters at correct positions with styles, (2) formatNode returns plain text without ANSI codes, (3) styled nodes render correctly without position corruption. The fix itself was already implemented - formatNode returns (text, style) tuple and charGrid applies styles at render time. All tests pass with race detector.

title: Add log rotation for event and debug logs
description:
# Description
Implement log rotation to prevent unbounded log file growth.

## Approach
Use startup rotation for event log (to preserve tail -f compatibility) and lumberjack for TUI debug log.

## Event Log (.atari/atari.log)
Startup rotation only - rename existing log on startup:
- On Start(), check if log exists and is > 0 bytes
- Rename to atari.log.2024-01-15T10-30-00.bak
- Create fresh log file
- This preserves atari events --follow behavior

Add disk warning:
- If existing log > 100MB, log warning about large log file
- Suggest manual cleanup of old .bak files

## TUI Debug Log (.atari/atari-debug.log)
Use lumberjack for automatic rotation:
- Not tailed by atari events, so mid-run rotation is safe
- MaxSize: 100MB, MaxBackups: 3, MaxAge: 7 days, Compress: true

title: Add session duration tracking to TUI
description:
# Description
Add duration tracking to the TUI to show both current bead elapsed time and total accumulated duration across all iterations. Display in human-friendly format.

# Requirements
- Track current bead elapsed time (live, updates on tick)
- Track total accumulated duration across all iterations
- Display format: "<60s" for under a minute, "Xm" for minutes, "Xh Ym" for hours
- Update on every 2s tick (no minute gating needed)
- Nil-safe handling for dropped events

# Implementation

## model.go
- Add StartTime (time.Time) to beadInfo struct
- Add to modelStats: TotalDurationMs (int64), CurrentDurationMs (int64)

## update.go handleEvent
- IterationStartEvent: capture event.Timestamp() to beadInfo.StartTime
- IterationEndEvent: accumulate e.DurationMs to TotalDurationMs, clear CurrentDurationMs

## update.go handleTick
- Always run stats sync (no gating)
- If currentBead != nil and StartTime is set: CurrentDurationMs = time.Since(StartTime)

## view.go renderHeader
- Line 2: append current elapsed in brackets after bead title: "bead: bd-123 - Title [5m]"
- Line 3: add total duration to stats line: "turns: 42  total: 1h 23m  completed: 4..."

## format.go
- Add formatDurationHuman(ms int64) string
- Returns "<60s", "Xm", "Xh", "Xh Ym"
- Handle negative/zero gracefully

## styles.go
- Add Duration style (color 220, same as Cost)

# Edge Cases
- Nil pointer safety: check iterationStartTime before use
- Event drops: log warning if IterationEndEvent without Start, use event DurationMs
- State loss on restart: accept (same as cost/turns behavior)
- Fallback mode: duration shows in IterationEndEvent format only (no live elapsed)

# Testing
- update_test.go: state transitions for duration fields
- format_test.go: formatDurationHuman boundary cases
- view_test.go: header rendering includes duration

# Verification
- [ ] mise run lint passes
- [ ] mise run test passes
- [ ] mise run build passes
close_reason: Implemented session duration tracking in TUI. Added StartTime to beadInfo, TotalDurationMs and CurrentDurationMs to modelStats. handleEvent captures start time on IterationStartEvent and accumulates duration on IterationEndEvent. handleTick computes live elapsed time. Added formatDurationHuman function for human-readable display (<60s, Xm, Xh, Xh Ym). Header shows current elapsed in brackets after bead title and total duration in stats line. Added 11 test cases for formatDurationHuman and 5 tests for duration tracking behavior. All lint, test, build pass.

title: Phase 6: Observer Mode
description:
# Overview
Implement interactive Q&A pane in the TUI for real-time understanding of drain activity and intervention guidance. Users can ask questions about what the drain is doing and get context-aware responses from Claude.

# Scope
- ObserverConfig for user customization
- Session broker for Claude process coordination (single-session rule)
- Log reader with rotation detection
- Context builder with structured prompts
- Observer query execution with --resume support
- TUI focus management for multi-pane support
- Observer pane UI component with textarea input
- Horizontal/vertical split layout
- CLI flags for observer configuration
- End-to-end tests and documentation

# Implementation Issues
- bd-drain-gwo: Add ObserverConfig to configuration system
- bd-drain-x97: Add session broker for Claude process coordination
- bd-drain-mgx: Create log reader with rotation detection
- bd-drain-656: Create event context builder for observer
- bd-drain-zlt: Implement observer query execution with Claude CLI
- bd-drain-8be: Add focus management to TUI model
- bd-drain-12j: Create observer pane UI component
- bd-drain-1ip: Integrate observer pane into main TUI with split layout
- bd-drain-bfk: Wire observer to controller and add CLI flags
- bd-drain-c8n: Add end-to-end tests and documentation for observer
- bd-drain-365: Run full test suite for Phase 6 observer (final verification)

# Verification Commands
- Lint: `mise run lint`
- Tests: `mise run test`

# Key Trade-offs
1. **Auto-pause vs always-available**: Observer auto-pauses drain during queries to maintain single-session rule. Trade-off: Brief interruption to drain for query safety.
2. **Wait-for-completion vs streaming**: MVP uses wait-for-completion for simplicity. Streaming deferred to future enhancement.
3. **Session broker vs true parallelism**: Chose coordination over complexity. Future: consider multiple model support.

# Design Decisions
- Session model: Uses `claude --resume <session_id>` for follow-up questions
- Context source: Reads from existing `.atari/atari.log` (no separate ring buffer)
- Structured context: Drain status, session history with costs, current bead events
- Event summarization: Tool name + description/file_path, truncated text (500 chars)
- Default model: Haiku for fast, low-cost Q&A
- Default layout: Horizontal (events left, observer right)

# Success Criteria
All implementation issues closed and final verification (bd-drain-365) passes.
close_reason: Phase 6 Observer Mode complete: ObserverConfig, SessionBroker, LogReader, ContextBuilder, Observer query execution, TUI focus management, observer pane UI, split layouts, CLI flags, E2E tests, and documentation all implemented and verified

- Press 'b' to open graph pane
- Shows "no beads to display"
- Refreshing (R) doesn't help
- The bead being worked on has no parent epic

# Hypothesis
The graph rendering code may assume all tasks are under epics and skip standalone tasks, or the layout algorithm fails when there's no hierarchy.

# Relevant Files
- internal/tui/graph.go - Graph building and layout logic
- internal/tui/graph_pane.go - Pane rendering
- internal/tui/fetcher.go - Data fetching from bd

# Investigation needed
- Check buildFromBeads() logic for standalone tasks
- Check if nodes without parents are being filtered out
- Check layout algorithm for single-node graphs
notes:
INVESTIGATION:
"No beads" shows when g.computed == nil OR len(g.nodes) == 0 (graph.go:637-638)

Possible causes:
1. Fetcher returned empty slice from bd list
2. buildFromBeads never called (data flow issue)
3. Graph not rebuilt after fetch completes

The layout logic itself handles standalone tasks correctly - they become roots.
Issue is likely in the data flow from fetcher to graph.
close_reason: Fixed race condition in graph pane refresh where fast fetches completed before requestID was set, causing results to be dropped as stale. Changed tea.Batch to chain commands: graphStartLoadingMsg now sets requestID first, then starts fetch via startFetch flag. Added two tests verifying the fix. All tests pass, lint clean.

- internal/tui/fetcher.go:44-47 (FetchBacklog - same issue)

title: Fix focus state when closing panes
description:

- model.go:206 (toggleGraph) - Check which panes are open before setting focus

Fix: When closing a pane, check eventsOpen first, then fall back to other open panes.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Focus always moves to an open pane when closing observer/graph
- If events closed and closing observer, focus moves to graph (if open)
- If events closed and closing graph, focus moves to observer (if open)

Verification:
- golangci-lint run passes
- go test -v ./internal/tui/... passes

title: Implement BD Activity Watcher core
description:
# Description
Create the core BD Activity Watcher component in internal/bdactivity. This watches bd activity --follow --json and emits events to the Router.

# Requirements
1. Create internal/bdactivity/watcher.go with:
   - Watcher struct with config, router, runner, logger
   - Start(ctx) error - begins watching (non-blocking)
   - Stop() error - graceful shutdown
   - Running() bool - status check
   - Iterative runLoop for reconnection (not recursive)
   - Backoff with reset after successful event
2. Use bufio.Reader.ReadBytes for line parsing (not Scanner)
3. Drain stderr in background goroutine
4. Kill process on context cancel, let pipes close naturally
5. Create internal/bdactivity/CLAUDE.md

# Design Notes
- Use atomic.Bool for running state
- Use done channel for shutdown coordination
- 1MB max line size with graceful handling
- Rate-limit parse warnings

# Relevant Files
- NEW: internal/bdactivity/watcher.go
- NEW: internal/bdactivity/CLAUDE.md
- Depends on: internal/runner, internal/events

# Acceptance Criteria
- Watcher starts and stops cleanly
- Reconnects on process failure with backoff
- Emits events to router
- No goroutine leaks

# Verification
- [ ] mise run lint passes
- [ ] mise run test passes
close_reason: Implemented BD Activity Watcher core in internal/bdactivity/watcher.go with: Start/Stop/Running lifecycle, iterative reconnect loop with exponential backoff, bufio.Reader for 1MB lines, stderr draining, rate-limited parse warnings, atomic running state. Added CLAUDE.md documentation.

title: Migrate Atari from beads (bd) to beads_rust (br)
description:
# Epic: Beads Rust Migration

Refactor Atari to use beads_rust (br) instead of original beads (bd). This is a clean break with no backward compatibility.

## Motivation
- Original beads has grown complex to support GasTown/orchestration features
- Atari needs only basic issue tracking (ready, update, close, show)
- beads_rust is intentionally simple (~20k LOC vs ~70k)
- Fewer dependencies, faster startup, simpler maintenance

## Key Decisions
- CLI naming: Hardcode br (clean break)
- Activity stream: File watcher on issues.jsonl
- Agent state: Structured logging (remove bd agent state)
- Epic closure: Implement in Atari
- Skill names: Generic /issue-* naming
- Missing binary: Fatal with install instructions
- Rollout: Big bang single PR

## Child Beads
See linked issues for implementation details.

## Verification
All beads complete, full E2E test passes, ready for merge.

title: Add positionNodesForList with indentation
description:
# Description
Implement list-mode positioning that calculates Y as cumulative line count and X as depth-based indentation.

# Changes
1. Add `positionNodesForList()` method to Graph in graph.go:
   - Iterate through ListOrder (visible nodes only)
   - Y = running sum of node heights (density-aware: 1/2/3 lines)
   - X = depth * 2 (2-space indent per level)
   - Clamp X to max viewport.Width/4 to prevent overflow
   - Width = viewport.Width - X (remaining space for content)
   - Store in Layout.Positions map

2. Update `computeLayout()` to call positionNodesForList() when LayoutMode is "list"

3. Handle edge cases:
   - Empty list: no positions to compute
   - Deep nesting: clamp indent to prevent negative width
   - Variable density: use nodeDimensions() for height

# Acceptance criteria

- Y increments by node height (density-aware)

title: Implement streaming JSON parser for Observer
description:
# Description
Implement streaming JSON parser in Observer to extract session_id from Claude stream-json output BEFORE truncation applies.

# Context
The Observer has a maxOutputBytes=100KB limit. If session_id appears after truncation point, it will be lost. Need to parse JSON events in streaming fashion to capture session_id early.

# Implementation Approach
1. Change Observer from --output-format text to --output-format stream-json
2. Parse JSON events line-by-line as they arrive
3. Extract session_id from result event immediately
4. Continue collecting text output for response
5. Handle truncation gracefully - session_id captured before limit hit

# Acceptance Criteria
- Observer uses stream-json format
- session_id extracted before truncation can occur
- Plain text result still returned to callers (API unchanged)
- Truncated responses still work (session_id captured early)

# Relevant Files
- internal/observer/observer.go - Main implementation (lines 183-240)
- internal/session/parser.go - Reference implementation for stream-json parsing

# Verification

- [ ] `mise run test` passes

If implementation reveals new issues, create separate bd issues for investigation.

title: Add wrap-up prompt before graceful stop
description:
# Description
Give Claude a chance to save progress notes before stopping on graceful pause.

# Technical Approach
1. Add method to session.go to inject a wrap-up prompt
2. On graceful pause at turn boundary, instead of immediate stop:
   - Inject prompt asking Claude to save progress via bd update
   - Wait for Claude to respond (up to 60s timeout)
   - Then stop session
3. Handle timeout by force stopping if no response

# Key Decisions
- Wrap-up asks Claude to update bead notes only (not commit)
- 60 second timeout before force stop
- Session ID should be captured after wrap-up completes

# Relevant Files
- internal/session/session.go - Add wrap-up prompt injection
- internal/controller/controller.go - Orchestrate wrap-up flow on graceful pause

# Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Graceful pause triggers wrap-up prompt before stop
- [ ] Claude has opportunity to run bd update with notes
- [ ] 60s timeout enforced, force stop if exceeded
- [ ] Session ends cleanly after wrap-up or timeout

# Verification
- [ ] mise run lint passes
- [ ] mise run test passes

If implementation reveals new issues, create separate bd issues for investigation.
close_reason: Implemented wrap-up prompt injection before graceful stop. On graceful pause at turn boundary, controller sends wrap-up prompt asking Claude to save progress via bd update, closes stdin to signal EOF, and enforces 60s timeout. Added WrapUpConfig, SendWrapUp/WrapUpSent/CloseStdin methods to session manager, and orchestration in controller. All tests pass.

title: Allow q to quit from observer normal mode
description:
# Description
The q keybind to quit doesn't work when the observer panel is focused. This is because all keys are forwarded to the observer pane when it's focused. In normal mode (not insert mode), q should still quit the application.

# Relevant files
- internal/tui/update.go:282-288 - forwards all keys to observer when focused
- internal/tui/observer_pane.go:203-271 - handleNormalModeKey doesn't handle q

# Solution
In observer_pane.go handleNormalModeKey, add a case for "q" that unfocuses the pane and signals the parent to quit. Alternatively, check insert mode in update.go before forwarding keys to observer.
close_reason: Fixed: q/p/r keys now work from observer panel in normal mode (not insert mode). Modified update.go to check IsInsertMode() before forwarding keys to observer. Updated tests to verify new behavior.

title: Add session_id validation and mutex protection
description:

Add validation for extracted session_id and ensure thread-safe access with mutex protection.

Current extractSessionID() is a TODO stub. Need to implement with proper validation and thread safety.

title: TUI: Fix graph rebuild race condition
description:
GraphPane.rebuildGraph() at graph_pane.go:293 calls g.graph.buildFromBeads(beads) without acquiring the graph mutex. The buildFromBeads method at graph.go:78 states it must be called with mu held.

Impact: Concurrent map writes can cause panic. Graph could be modified while rendering which holds RLock.

Fix: Either call g.graph.RebuildFromBeads() which handles locking, or acquire lock before calling buildFromBeads.

title: List view uses wrong arrow keys for navigation
description:
# Description
In list view, navigation uses left/right arrow keys to move through the list instead of up/down. This is unintuitive for a vertical list - users expect up/down to move through items.

# Root cause
The key mapping in graph_pane.go:217-244 was designed for grid layout:
- up/k  SelectParent() (hierarchy: move to parent)
- down/j  SelectChild() (hierarchy: move to child)
- left/h  SelectPrev() (linear: previous in list)
- right/l  SelectNext() (linear: next in list)

In list mode, SelectPrev/SelectNext do the linear list traversal, but they're bound to left/right instead of up/down.

# Current behavior (wrong)
```
up/k     jumps to parent node (hierarchy)
down/j   jumps to first child (hierarchy)
left/h   previous item in list (linear)
right/l  next item in list (linear)
```

# Expected behavior
```
up/k     previous item in list (linear)
down/j   next item in list (linear)
left/h   collapse current / go to parent (optional)
right/l  expand current / go to child (optional)
```

# Relevant code
- graph_pane.go:217-244 - key handling in handleKey()
- Need to check layout mode and swap bindings

# Fix approach
In handleKey(), check if layout mode is list:
```go
case "up", "k":
    if g.layoutMode == GraphLayoutList {
        p.graph.SelectPrev()  // Linear up in list
    } else {
        p.graph.SelectParent()  // Hierarchy in grid
    }

case "down", "j":
    if g.layoutMode == GraphLayoutList {
        p.graph.SelectNext()  // Linear down in list
    } else {
        p.graph.SelectChild()  // Hierarchy in grid
    }
```

# Acceptance criteria
- In list view: up/down moves linearly through the list
- In list view: j/k also moves linearly (vim style)
- Navigation feels natural for a vertical list

# Verification
- [ ] `golangci-lint run` passes
- [ ] `go test -v ./...` passes
- [ ] Manual test: up/down navigates list items
close_reason: Fixed list view navigation keys. Swapped bindings so up/down/j/k navigate linearly through list items while left/right/h/l navigate hierarchy. Verified with lint (0 issues) and all tests pass.
